Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cognitive and Neural Indicators of School-based Improvements in Spatial Problem Solving

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, to be conducted by James Madison University, Georgetown University, and Northwestern University, will examine learning spatial thinking skills by high school students (who are studying geoscience), looking at educational outcomes as well as behavioral and neurological measures. There is already considerable evidence linking spatial ability and future STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) attainment. The project will focus on a high school course, the Geospatial Semester, that is designed to improve spatial thinking. The project will look for changes in patterns of brain activity as a result of the course, as well as relations among the educational, behavioral, and neurological measures. Prior research indicates that spatial training in the laboratory may reduce gender differences in performance; this project will seek to measure this effect in real world high school spatial learning, and to identify neural mechanisms that help explain how and why the gender gap closes. This project will advance the work of the EHR (Education & Human Resources) Directorate in studying the cognitive and neural basis of STEM learning.

The overall goal of the project is to develop a mechanistic theory of change for spatial STEM education at the behavioral and neural levels. To achieve this goal, the project will measure a combination of outcomes: educational (e.g., coursework), behavioral (e.g., core spatial ability on standard tests of mental rotation and embedded figure identification, use of spatial language), and neurological (e.g., neural efficiency and grey matter volume in brain regions that support spatial thinking ability, interconnectivity networks across brain regions). Students in the spatially-based Geospatial Semester will be compared to peers receiving standard (non-spatially-based) STEM education in other advanced science courses. Neurological measures will be obtained by functional and structural magnetic resonance imaging performed at pre- and post-test time points. In general, the project will address the issue of brain plasticity in a high school STEM education context. The project will use machine learning techniques to discern neurological effects of spatial learning in both hypothesis-driven and data-driven ways, and examine gender differences in the effect of spatial STEM learning on cognition and the brain. Analyses will focus on relating changes across neural, behavioral, and educational levels toward an integrated understanding of the mechanisms that make spatial STEM learning effective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the effects of spatially-enriched STEM education in a real-world classroom setting (the Geospatial Semester; GSS) on cognitive and brain-based measures of spatial and verbal thinking and reasoning. This project helps to bridge a critical gap between the cognitive neuroscience laboratory and the high school classroom. Applying neuroimaging allowed us to determine not only whether changes occur with learning but also to develop biological inferences about how these changes occur. To our knowledge, this is the first research to measure how learning in a real-world high school class changes the brain over time. This research design is essential to measuring change (and the mechanism of change) associated with the content of in-school learning.

We have now gathered data that indicate effects of spatial education at levels of near, intermediate, and far transfer. Note that all results are preliminary at this stage. Participation in the spatially enriched GSS curriculum (relative to control) appears to have increased the use of spatial thinking to solve problems as measured by the “Spatial Habits of Mind (SHoM)” survey. This suggests that exposure to and experience with geospatial mapping software in the GSS changed the way students thought about real-world problems, making them more likely to take a spatial approach. This result provides support for one of our hypotheses and is a clear demonstration of efficacy of the GSS.

At the level of intermediate transfer, the data indicate that spatial learning in the classroom transferred to improved performance on an untrained “embedded figures” spatial task (intermediate transfer), and even to a task of verbal deductive reasoning (far transfer). Prior research has shown that different search strategies are possible within this task (i.e., more spatial strategies in which objects are mentally manipulated in space vs. More purely visual search in which objects are not manipulated). More spatial approaches have been associated with better performance.

Perhaps most notably, GSS students showed improved performance on the deductive reasoning task. This is a particularly exciting finding because it represents true “far transfer” of a real-world classroom curriculum. Students were never taught reasoning strategies in GSS. Critically, improvement on reasoning was observed even for verbal stimuli that did not include overtly spatial relations (e.g., “happier” as opposed to “above”). This far transfer is directly in line with our hypotheses based on underlying “mental modeling” (established by its own extensive literature) that is thought to support reasoning in a broad and flexible way. However, no prior research has tested whether improving spatial cognition can improve reasoning, and to do this in a real-world classroom is especially exciting.

A finding of particular interest with relevance to STEM inclusion was that GSS students showed a closing of the gender gap in spatial performance whereby female students performed on par with male students by the end of the school year. This closing of the gap was not observed in the quasi-experimentally matched control group.

Brain imaging of participants indicated that GSS students showed increased activation in the parietal cortex during overtly spatial tasks and thee deductive reasoning task; this increased activity was related to improved performance on spatial thinking and verbal reasoning. Functional connectivity analysis showed increased connectivity to motor and parietal cortices during the reasoning task. Altogether, these results indicate that GSS students may have adopted a more spatial strategy (at both the neural and behavioral level) for solving reasoning problems, which resulted in improved performance.

This project’s demonstration of far transfer from in-classroom spatial teaching to improvements in verbal reasoning (associated with changes in spatial habits of mind and the recruitment and connectivity of spatial brain resources) may be a landmark finding in STEM education. Spatial thinking has repeatedly been shown to be a very strong predictor of STEM achievement, persistence, and attainment in STEM fields, even after accounting for other relevant variables such as mathematical and verbal aptitude. In some STEM fields (e.g., engineering), spatial ability even contributes more unique variance than SAT scores to the prediction of achievement and attainment. Likewise, the ability to reason is among the most generalizable and important cognitive skills for achievement across academic and professional pursuits, including in STEM. Thus, demonstrating a real-world means (spatial education) and an associated neural mechanism (increased recruitment and connectivity of spatial brain resources) for bolstering both spatial thinking and deductive reasoning has far-reaching implications.

Based on the success of this study, we anticipate that these results are likely to have substantial impacts for the adoption of spatially-based teaching strategies in schools, and the study of real-world classroom learning by neuroscience.
